contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=May 2007}} '''Janet Ayer Fairbank''' (June 7, 1878 - December 28, 1951) was an American author and [[suffragette]], socially and politically active in Chicago and a champion of progressive causes. She attended the [[University of Chicago]] and in 1900 married the lawyer Kellogg Fairbank, the son of industrialist [[N. K. Fairbank]]. They had three children including the operatic singer [[Janet Fairbank]] (1903â€“1947).<ref>http://jcgi.pathfinder.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,934730,00.html</ref> She was a delegate to the [[Democratic National Convention]] from Illinois in 1924 and 1932.<ref>http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/faalevao-fairbanks.html</ref> She was the older sister of [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning author [[Margaret Ayer Barnes]]. == Bibliography == * ''Home'' (1910) * ''The Cortlandts of Washington Square'' (1923) * ''The Smiths'' (1925) (runner-up for the [[Pulitzer Prize]]) * ''Idle Hands'' (1927) (short stories) * ''The Lion's Den'' (1930) * ''The Bright Land'' (1932) * ''Rich Man, Poor Man'' (1936) ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=76020276}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fairbank, Janet Ayer}} {{Persondata |NAME = Fairbank, Janet Ayer |ALTERNATIVE NAMES = |SHORT DESCRIPTION = Novelist, suffragette |DATE OF BIRTH = June 7, 1878 |PLACE OF BIRTH = |DATE OF DEATH = December 28, 1951 |PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{US-story-writer-stub}} [[Category:1878 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:American short story writers]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Place of death missing]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:American women novelists]]
